storybook.title: Data Resources for Patient-Centered Outcomes Research at Federally Qualified Health Centers
storybook.subtitle: The National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey Health Center Component

scenes.scene_title: Introduction: The NAMCS Health Center Ecosystem
scenes.narrative_purpose: Set the context by introducing the key players, concepts, and relationships in the NAMCS HC Component ecosystem. Show how FQHCs, NCHS, HRSA, and PCOR are interconnected.

nodes.label: NAMCS HC Component
nodes.description: Redesigned survey collecting EHR visit data from health centers since 2021

nodes.label: FQHCs
nodes.description: Federally Qualified Health Centers serving 31.3 million patients

nodes.label: FQHC Look-alikes
nodes.description: Health centers meeting HRSA requirements without Program funding

nodes.label: NCHS
nodes.description: National Center for Health Statistics - conducts the survey

nodes.label: HRSA
nodes.description: Health Resources and Services Administration - oversees Health Center Program

nodes.label: HUD
nodes.description: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development - external linkage partner

nodes.label: EHR Data
nodes.description: Electronic Health Records submitted by participating centers

nodes.label: Uniform Data System
nodes.description: HRSA reporting system for health center characteristics

nodes.label: PCOR
nodes.description: Patient-Centered Outcomes Research

nodes.label: Health Professional Shortage Areas
nodes.description: Underserved areas where FQHCs provide critical healthcare

nodes.label: Researchers
nodes.description: Users of datafiles and dashboards for healthcare research

nodes.label: Patients
nodes.description: 67.3% in poverty, served by health centers

nodes.label: Policymakers
nodes.description: Use data for evidence-based decision making

nodes.label: Interactive Dashboard
nodes.description: Biannual preliminary estimates visualization tool

nodes.label: Datafiles
nodes.description: Restricted and public use datasets for research

scenes.narrative_text: The NAMCS Health Center Component represents a comprehensive ecosystem connecting federal agencies, healthcare providers, and research communities. At its core, the NCHS-administered survey collects electronic health record data from Federally Qualified Health Centers and their look-alikes—community-based settings that serve 31.3 million patients in health professional shortage areas. This data flows into research products including datafiles and interactive dashboards, enabling patient-centered outcomes research that benefits patients, researchers, and policymakers alike. External linkages to agencies like HUD expand the analytical possibilities, creating a powerful infrastructure for understanding healthcare delivery to underserved populations.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Highlight the critical role of FQHCs in serving underserved populations and the stark differences between FQHC patients and the general U.S. population.
scenes.narrative_text: Federally Qualified Health Centers serve as a critical safety net for America's most vulnerable populations. In 2023, FQHCs provided care to 31.3 million patients—approximately 1 in 11 Americans. The disparity is stark: while only 11.1% of the overall U.S. population lives in poverty, 67.3% of FQHC patients fall below the poverty line. These centers operate primarily in Health Professional Shortage Areas, filling gaps where traditional healthcare infrastructure is insufficient.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Explain the four-step data collection methodology and sampling strategy that enables nationally representative data collection.

nodes.label: Step 1: Contact & Agreement
nodes.description: NCHS contacts sampled health centers to gain participation agreement

nodes.label: Step 2: Questionnaire
nodes.description: ~45-minute questionnaire for survey weight calculation

nodes.label: Step 3: HL7 Implementation
nodes.description: Install HL7 CDA R2 Implementation Guide template

nodes.label: Step 4: Testing & Validation
nodes.description: T&V file submitted for quality assessment

nodes.label: EHR Data Submission
nodes.description: Final EHR datafiles submitted to NCHS

scenes.narrative_text: The NAMCS HC Component employs a rigorous four-step data collection process. From a sampling frame of approximately 1,400 health centers, a primary sample of 50 is drawn along with a reserve sample of 100 to replace any declining centers. Each participating center completes a questionnaire, implements the HL7 CDA R2 standard for EHR data formatting, passes testing and validation, and then submits their complete EHR visit data. This process yielded 29 participating centers in the inaugural 2021 collection cycle.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Illustrate the dual-track data access model with restricted and public use datafiles, showing what researchers can access at each level.

children.label: Variables: Full set including PII, labs, medications

scenes.narrative_text: Researchers have two pathways to access NAMCS HC Component data. The restricted use datafile contains millions of complete records with the full set of data elements including procedures, lab tests, and medications—accessible through the NCHS Research Data Center with an application and fee. For broader accessibility, the public use datafile offers a 5% sample with survey weights for nationally representative estimates, available for free download with no programming knowledge required.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Demonstrate the analytical power of the data through maternal health visit patterns across age groups.

matrix.title: Maternal Health Visits to Health Centers by Age Group (2023)

scenes.narrative_text: Analysis of 2023 NAMCS HC Component data reveals significant age-based patterns in maternal health care. Women aged 20-29 had the highest maternal health visit rate (134.6 per 1,000), followed by those aged 30-39 (101.0). Gestational diabetes visits showed a different pattern, with women 30-39 having the highest rate (4.3 per 1,000). These findings demonstrate the analytical depth possible with visit-level data, enabling research on age-related differences in maternal morbidity and complications.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Reveal racial/ethnic disparities in respiratory disease visits over time, demonstrating the dashboard's analytical capabilities.

timeline.title: Lung/Breathing-related Disease Visit Rates by Race/Ethnicity (per 1,000 people)

scenes.narrative_text: The NAMCS HC Component dashboard reveals persistent racial/ethnic disparities in respiratory health. From 2022 through mid-2024, Hispanic and Non-Hispanic Black populations consistently showed significantly higher visit rates for lung/breathing-related diseases (25-37 per 1,000) compared to Non-Hispanic White populations (10-14 per 1,000). These disparities persisted across all measured time periods, highlighting the need for targeted respiratory health interventions in minority communities served by health centers.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Show how linking NAMCS HC data to external sources (HUD) creates new research possibilities for understanding social determinants of health.

sankey.title: NAMCS HC Component to HUD Data Linkage Flow

scenes.narrative_text: Data linkage exponentially expands research possibilities. Of the 727,232 patients in the 2021 NAMCS HC Component, 99.9% were eligible for linkage with HUD housing assistance data using deterministic and probabilistic matching. The resulting 3.6% linkage rate (26,128 patients) enables unprecedented research into how housing stability affects health outcomes. Notably, linkage rates were highest among elderly patients (4.7%) and females (4.1%), suggesting these populations may benefit most from integrated housing-health research.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Visualize the dramatic growth of the NAMCS HC Component in participating centers and visit records.
scenes.narrative_text: The NAMCS HC Component has experienced remarkable growth since its 2021 redesign. Participating health centers more than tripled from 29 to 95, while visit records grew from 3.5 million to over 9 million—a 154% increase. Perhaps most impressive is the 98.4% retention rate in 2023, demonstrating that once health centers join the program, they recognize its value and continue participating. This growing foundation ensures increasingly robust and representative data for health center research.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Present the survey's limitations transparently while showing mitigation strategies.

matrix.title: NAMCS HC Component Limitations and Mitigations

rows.mitigation: Primary/reserve sampling strategy, set-up fee incentive, 98.4% retention rate

rows.description: Not all EHR data elements available in public files
rows.mitigation: Restricted access available at RDC, exploration of adding elements to future public files

rows.description: Some health centers have missing values for certain elements
rows.mitigation: Weight normalization technique: New weight = Original weight × (Sum all / Sum included)

scenes.narrative_text: Transparency about limitations strengthens research credibility. While the NAMCS HC Component's response rate (42.2% year-specific, 30.2% overall in 2023) is lower than ideal, the exceptional 98.4% retention rate and growing sample compensate for initial recruitment challenges. Data element availability in public files is limited for confidentiality, but researchers can access the full dataset through the Research Data Center. For data missingness, NCHS provides a weight normalization formula that ensures estimates remain nationally representative even when some centers have incomplete data.

scenes.narrative_purpose: Summarize key achievements and outline future directions including planned data linkages and expanded capabilities.

root.label: NAMCS HC Component: The Road Ahead
root.description: A growing resource for patient-centered outcomes research

children.label: 2024 Datafiles
children.description: Restricted and public use files forthcoming

key_takeaways.title: Unprecedented Access
key_takeaways.description: The NAMCS HC Component provides the first nationally representative EHR-based visit data from health centers.

key_takeaways.title: Dual Access Model
key_takeaways.description: Restricted datafiles for detailed research and public use files for broad accessibility.

key_takeaways.title: Growing Infrastructure
key_takeaways.description: From 29 to 95 centers in three years with 98.4% retention.

key_takeaways.title: Linkage Power
key_takeaways.description: Integration with NDI, HUD, and soon Medicaid data.

key_takeaways.title: Actionable Insights
key_takeaways.description: Interactive dashboards bring timely data to all stakeholders within 6 months.

scenes.narrative_text: The NAMCS HC Component has transformed from an ambitious redesign into a proven resource for understanding healthcare at federally qualified health centers. With 95 participating centers, over 9 million annual visits, and a 98.4% retention rate, the foundation is strong. Completed linkages to the National Death Index and HUD housing data, combined with the ongoing Medicaid linkage, create unprecedented opportunities to study how social determinants affect health outcomes for the 31.3 million patients served by health centers. As 2024 datafiles approach release and new dashboard modules expand analytical capabilities, the NAMCS HC Component stands ready to serve researchers, clinicians, patients, and policymakers in their shared mission to improve health outcomes for America's most vulnerable populations.
